Exactly! Setting specific goals for each short session can help you stay focused, motivated, and give you a sense of accomplishment. It's a great way to break down your larger goals into manageable, bite-sized chunks. By achieving these smaller goals, you'll build momentum and confidence, which will carry over to your longer weekend sessions.

**Remember to make your goals SMART:**

1. **Specific**: Clearly define what you want to achieve in each short session.
2. **Measurable**: Quantify your goals so you can track progress (e.g., "I will practice finger independence exercises for 10 minutes").
3. **Achievable**: Set realistic goals that are challenging yet attainable.
4. **Relevant**: Align your short-session goals with your larger piano goals.
5. **Time-bound**: Set a specific time frame for each short session (e.g., 10-15 minutes).

By making your goals SMART, you'll be able to track your progress, stay focused, and celebrate your achievements.

**Celebrate your successes!**

Don't forget to acknowledge and celebrate your achievements, no matter how small they may seem. This will help you stay motivated and encouraged throughout your piano journey.

How do you plan to track your progress and celebrate your successes? Will you use a practice journal, a habit-tracking app, or something else?
